text:
<@U014FMGRKQA> I have been in this position for sure. We are a larger org now but I’ve been here for 5+ years in different roles so I’ve particularly struggled with “residual” tasks after my role changed to focus on content. 

I do think the team growing helps, but the requests you’re getting now are a great opportunity for you to shape the direction of that growth and make a recommendation. Of the things you are asked to support, which are highly valuable for the business? If your team isn’t best to support, could anyone else take them on permanently or could you make a case for a freelancer (eg for graphic design—could you hire someone to make templates your team could use, or just do the design)? I’ve also found it helpful to tell other people the “why” and share priorities when declining a request...on lean teams I feel like everyone gets it and if it’s possible to suggest an alternative solution that might help.

elements.text:

If your team isn’t best to support, could anyone else take them on permanently or could you make a case for a freelancer (eg for graphic design—could you hire someone to make templates your team could use, or just do the design)? I’ve also found it helpful to tell other people the “why” and share priorities when declining a request...on lean teams I feel like everyone gets it and if it’s possible to suggest an alternative solution that might help.

And are we talking about from lead-to-opportunity or industry standards for contract length?

text: <@UUH2EB134> Don’t have specific details from them yet on sales cycle, requesting all that information as part of our research phase if they want to move forward. The product is a biodiesel generator (size of a 20ft shipping container), unit cost is over USD$100K and requires a $10k deposit on purchase. unit production is 6-9 months as well, so it’s a very considered purchase. We’re also looking at India as a test market which comes with localisation challenges too. Audience ranges from Farmer Co-ops to NGO’s and GO’s

text: Given the wide breadth of customer segments, it might make sense to focus on highly segmented/verticalized content at the bottom of the funnel — case studies and sales enablement. That way the sales teams have the right content when prospects are in decision-making mode. From there, you can use all the insight gathered from case study interviews to build up the funnel. The rest is going to depend on distribution.

elements.text: Given the wide breadth of customer segments, it might make sense to focus on highly segmented/verticalized content at the bottom of the funnel — case studies and sales enablement. That way the sales teams have the right content when prospects are in decision-making mode. From there, you can use all the insight gathered from case study interviews to build up the funnel. The rest is going to depend on distribution.

text:
Hi all. I'm developing a "brand impact" score/equation and wanted to see if any of you a) have an equation or 2) attempted to do something like this before and if it's working for your org. The idea behind this "score" is to create a leaderboard (and stimulate some healthy competition) at my firm to get individuals more involved with our marketing efforts. Would appreciate any thoughts/feedback on my WIP equation. Thanks!

The multiplier in front of each variable is mostly weighted to represent the individual's involved time/effort (higher the number, the more time/effort they need to put in). I also think I should be accounting for: level of impact, size of audience, and content value (ie can it be repurposed and repackaged into content, social, etc).

*Brand impact = 2 (Content) + 1 (Social) + 2 (PR) + 3 (Events)*

*Content*
# of blog posts

*Social*
# of Tweets and LinkedIn posts* *(can include other social channels, but we primarily use these platforms)

*PR*
# of speaking engagements
# of media interviews
# of mentions

*Events*
# of events * participation score (sponsor-high, contributor role-medium, attended-low) 
Audience size
